title: Lindenwald
listingDescription: Lindenwald is Van Buren's post-presidency home located at Martin Van Buren National Historic Site

images.altText: Photo of Van Buren's home draped in snow taken through tree branches.
images.title: Lindenwald in Snow
images.caption: Van Buren's "Lindenwald" served as a home, farm and political headquarters.

relatedParks.fullName: Martin Van Buren National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Martin Van Buren

bodyText: Lindenwald is the name that Van Buren gave to the home and farm he would cultivate here after his presidency. A home was originally built here in 1792, and after Van Buren's purchase of the property in 1839 it would be modified to the appearance it retains today. The building is an eccentric mix of Federalist, Italianate, and Gothic Victorian styles as a result of Van Buren's renovations to the house, which included the tower on the south-west corner of the home. The home served as a political headquarters for Van Buren during his attempts to be reelected, and a place of work for the many domestic servants and farm workers that he needed to operate his residence.
audioDescription: A wide brick house painted yellow. Lindenwald, which is what Van Buren called his home, is a three story tall building that is an eccentric mix of different architectural styles. Looking at the front of the building, the first two floors have large windows with shutters painted the same color as the home looking out at the front lawn. The third floor has small dormer windows peaking out through the eaves of the roof. Over the roofline of the rest of the roof from the rear of the home, rises a four story tower with a roofed platform open to the air at the top.

quickFacts.value: Post Presidency home of Martin Van Buren
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: The Old Sycamore
listingDescription: Oldest tree in Martin Van Buren National Historic Site

images.altText: Aerial View of Old Sycamore Tree in Fall
images.title: Aerial View of Old Sycamore Tree
images.caption: This aerial photo of the old sycamore was taken from the height of Lindenwald's tower

relatedParks.fullName: Martin Van Buren National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Martin Van Buren

bodyText: The oldest tree on the park grounds is the American Sycamore tree behind Van Buren's home. The towering tree stands taller than the tower of Van Buren's home, and requires multiple people to join hands at its base to go around it. Sycamore trees can live for over 200 years under the correct circumstances, but it is impossible to know for sure exactly how old our sycamore is without damaging it. This is because depending on environmental factors trees can grow at different rates, the only way to know exactly how the old the tree is would be to take cores out and count rings. By growth estimates however the tree is believed to have originated from Van Buren's time on the property making it the only witness tree to his time here.
audioDescription: The Sycamore tree towers out of the ground behind Van Buren's home. It is wide enough at the base that many people would have to join hands to ring all the way around it. It is almost as wide at the top as it is tall.

title: The Van Buren Farm
listingDescription: The farm at Martin Van Buren National Historic Site is a tangible part of Van Buren's legacy as it is still active today!

images.altText: An aerial photo looking out towards the farm fields with visitor center in foreground
images.title: Aerial Photo of Farm From Visitor Center
images.caption: A portion of Van Buren's historic farm can be reached by heading behind the visitor center.

relatedParks.fullName: Martin Van Buren National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Martin Van Buren

tags: Martin Van Buren National Historic Site
bodyText: Van Buren was a passionate farm manager in the later years of his life. Following Jefferson's example after his presidency he decided to try his hand at being a gentleman farmer. Van Buren's twenty years here though are only a small part of the hundreds of years of agricutural heritage in the area. The farm remains active today, and each year the fields are planted with different crops. As the farm is active we do ask that visitors stay on the park trails.
audioDescription: Farm fields stretch out to a line of trees at the horizon. The line of trees mark the Kinderhook Creek which is the edge of Van Buren's historic property.

quickFacts.value: Area actively farmed for over 400 years.
quickFacts.name: Significance
